questions.text: A pregnant woman has come for her first antenatal visit at 10 weeks of gestation. How many more antenatal visits does she require to fulfill the minimum requirements as per the Maternal and Child Health program?
questions.solution:
This patient requires 3 more antenatal visits in order to fulfill the minimum requirements according to the Maternal and Child Health Program (MCH).

The minimum number of antenatal visits according to MCH is 4.

  • 1st visit – within 12 weeks, preferably as soon as the pregnancy is suspected.
  • 2nd visit – between 14 and 26 weeks
  • 3rd visit – between 28 and 34 weeks
  • 4th visit – between 36 weeks and term

The minimum number of antenatal visits according to the WHO is 8. Ideally, pregnant women should attend antenatal visits according to the following schedule:

  • Once a month during the first 7 months
  • Twice a month during the 8th month
  • Once a week, thereafter if everything is normal.

questions.text: Which of the following vaccine is contraindicated in pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Varicella vaccine is contraindicated in pregnant women as it is a live vaccine. 

The live attenuated varicella virus vaccine is currently recommended for children between 12 to 18 months of age who have not had chickenpox.

questions.text: What is the average weight gain during pregnancy in Indian women with inadequate calorie intake?
questions.solution:
Weight gain during pregnancy in women with inadequate calorie intake is around 5 - 6 kgs.

Normally, a woman is expected to gain around 9-11 kgs of weight during pregnancy. An inadequate dietary intake can be suspected if the woman gains < 2 kg/ month.

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect about congenital syphilis?

choices.text: It can be prevented by procaine penicillin administration
Infection of fetus most commonly occurs in the 1st trimester
Neurological damage with mental retardation is a serious complication
Chances of transmission are lower if mother has late syphilis

questions.solution:
The chances of transmission of syphilis during pregnancy is highest after 6th month of gestation. It does not occur before the 4th month.

It is routine to test the mother for syphilis in antenatal clinics during her first visit. The chance of infection of the fetus is higher when the mother is suffering from early (primary or secondary) syphilis and are lower in case of late syphilis. Neurological damage with mental retardation is a serious complication of congenital syphilis. It can be prevented by procaine penicillin administration.

questions.text: The District Maternal Death Review Committee is reviewing the number of maternal deaths in the district during 2020. In order to calculate the maternal mortality ratio, what other parameter is required?

choices.text: Total women in child bearing age

questions.solution:
The maternal mortality ratio is calculated using the number of maternal deaths and total live births.

India's MMR is 103 per 1,00,000 live births as per SRS (Sample Registration System) Bulletin 2017-2019.  It has declined by 7.3% from 122 in 2015-17.


Note: India's MMR is 97 per 1,00,000 live births as per SRS (Sample Registration System) Bulletin 2018-2020.  

Related Pearl: Maternal Mortality Ratio

Maternal death is defined as the death of a woman while pregnant or within 42 days of termination of pregnancy, irrespective of the duration and site of pregnancy, from any cause related to or aggravated by the pregnancy or its management but not from accidental or incidental causes.

The main global causes of maternal deaths are severe bleeding, indirect causes (anemia, malaria, heart diseases), infections, unsafe abortions, eclampsia, obstructed labor, and other direct causes like ectopic pregnancy, anesthesia-related complications, etc.

In India, the most common causes of maternal deaths are hemorrhage (leading cause), sepsis, obstructed labor, hypertensive disorders, etc.

questions.text: Which of the following maternal deaths is not included when calculating the maternal mortality ratio?

choices.text: Death of a 30-year-old woman following spontaneous abortion at 11 weeks of gestation
Death of a 24-year-old woman due to ruptured ectopic pregnancy
Death of a 26-year-old woman following a road traffic accident at 36 weeks of gestation
Death of a 21-year-woman following secondary PPH on postpartum day 14

questions.solution:
The death of a pregnant woman following a road traffic accident is not included when calculating the maternal mortality ratio. It includes all deaths anytime during pregnancy or within 42 days of termination from any cause related to or aggravated by the pregnancy.

questions.text:
In a town, there were 2500 live births in a period of 6 months. During the same period, 15 women died due to the following causes. What is the maternal mortality ratio?

Peripartum infection - 5

Electrocution - 5

Obstructed labor - 2

Postpartum hemorrhage - 3
questions.solution:
The maternal mortality ratio (MMR) of this town is 400 per 100,000 live births.

Maternal mortality refers to deaths during pregnancy or 42 days within termination, from causes related to pregnancy. Hence, in this town, there were 10 maternal deaths (peripartum infection, PPH, obstructed labor).

MMR = Number of maternal deaths in a period x 100,000 / Number of live births in the same period

Hence, MMR = 10 x 100000/2500 = 400 per 100,000 live births

questions.text: A baby was delivered at home in a village. Until which day of life should an ASHA worker visit this baby?
questions.solution:
Under the Home Based Newborn Care (HBNC) guidelines, ASHA workers should visit all newborns up to 42 days of life, according to the following schedule. 

Mode of delivery No. of visits Schedule of visits
Home delivery 7 Days 1, 3, 7, 14, 21, 28, 42
Hospital-based normal vaginal delivery 6

Days 3, 7, 14, 21, 28, 42

(except day 1)
Hospital-based LSCS delivery 5

Days 7, 14, 21, 28, 42

(except days 1, 3)

During her visits, ASHA workers must record weight, ensure vaccination, and registration of births. On completion of all these visits, they receive an incentive of Rs. 250. 

Related Pearl: ASHA

ASHA stands for Accredited Social Health Activist.

General norms with respect to ASHA workers:

  • Must be a woman in the age group of 25-45 years - married/divorced/widow
  • Must be a resident of that village
  • Formal education of up to 10th standard 
    • If no candidates are available, the requirement can be relaxed to the 8th standard
  • At least 1 ASHA for a population of 1000 
    • In tribal, hilly, and desert areas, the norm can be relaxed to 1 ASHA per habitation

States can relax the norms on population and educational qualifications on a case-to-case basis, depending on the local conditions. However, these are exceptions and not the general norm.

Responsibilities of ASHA:

    • Health education and awareness
    • Reproductive and child health and family planning
    • Facilitate the access to health services
    • Promotion of sanitation and household toilet construction
    • Provision of primary medical care for minor ailments
    • Provider of DOTS
    • Depot holder of essentials like ORS, iron and folic acid tablets, condoms, disposable delivery kits, etc.
    • Dispersal of health information on her community to higher centres
    • Some responsibilities are integrated with Anganwadi workers and Auxiliary Nurse Midwife

Home visits by ASHA under Home-based Newborn care (HBNC) 

  • 7 visits after home delivery (on days 1, 3, 7, 14, 21, 28 and 42)
  • 6 visits after institutional delivery (on days 3, 7, 14, 21, 28 and 42) in case of a vaginal delivery; and 5 visits in cases of Caesarean section delivery, where the mother returns home after 5-6 days, i.e, on days - 7, 14, 21, 28 and 42.

Home visits by ASHA under Home-based care of young child (HBYC)

  • A total of 5 visits are scheduled after 42 days under the Home-Based Care of the Young Child(HBYC).
  • ASHA will provide quarterly home visits on the 3rd, 6th, 9th, 12th and 15th months

questions.text: What is the best indicator of obstetric and neonatal care given before and around the time of birth?
questions.solution:
The perinatal mortality rate is the best indicator to evaluate obstetric and neonatal care given before and around the time of birth.

Related Pearl: Perinatal Mortality Rate

  • The term ‘perinatal mortality’ includes both late fetal death (stillbirths) and early neonatal deaths.
  • Babies chosen for inclusion in perinatal statistics should be above a minimum birth weight (1000g at birth). If the birth weight is not available, a gestation period of at least 28 weeks should be used (as the weight at 28 weeks corresponds to 1000g). If both are not available, then crown to heel length of at least 35cm should be used.
  • Generally, the PMR = Late fetal deaths and early neonatal deaths weighing over 1000g at birth x 1000/Total births(live+dead) weighing over 1000g at birth.
  • The PMR is the yard-stick of obstetric and pediatric care before and around the time of birth.
  • The PMR of India (2016) is 24 per 1000 births.
  • The main causes of perinatal mortality are intrauterine and birth asphyxia, low birth weight, birth trauma, and intrauterine/neonatal infections.

Please note that the actual perinatal period commences from the 22nd week of life, but at that time the fetus weighs only about 500g.

Therefore, only for statistical calculations and international comparisons, to calculate the perinatal mortality rate, the period from the 28th week of life is taken, as then the baby weighs about 1000g. As mentioned, babies included in the perinatal statistics must weigh above 1000g.

questions.text: What is the 2030 target of the India Newborn Action Plan with regards to the stillbirth rate?
questions.solution:
The India Newborn Action Plan targets to achieve a stillbirth rate of < 10/ 1000 live births and neonatal mortality rate of < 10/ 1000 live births (single-digit SBR and NMR) by 2030.

This program was launched to reduce preventable newborn deaths and stillbirths. It provides the following:

  • Pre-conception and antenatal care
  • Care during labor and childbirth
  • Immediate newborn care
  • Care of healthy newborn
  • Care of small and sick newborn
  • Care beyond newborn survival

questions.text:
A group of health workers are conducting a perinatal mortality audit in a hospital. Which of the following must they take into account to calculate the perinatal mortality rate?
  1. No. of live births per year
  2. No. of stillbirths over 1000 g per year
  3. No. of stillbirths after 22 weeks of gestation
  4. No. of early neonatal deaths per year
  5. No. of late neonatal deaths per year
questions.solution:
The perinatal mortality rate (PMR) is calculated using the following parameters during a particular time period:

  • Late fetal deaths or stillbirths > 1000 g - correlates to 28 weeks of gestation
  • Early neonatal deaths - from birth to 7 days of life
  • Live births > 1000 g

The neonatal mortality rate (NMR) refers to the deaths within the first 28 days of life. It is calculated using the following parameters:

  • Early neonatal deaths
  • Late neonatal deaths - after 7th day but before 28th completed day of life

Related Pearl: Perinatal Mortality Rate

  • The term ‘perinatal mortality’ includes both late fetal death (stillbirths) and early neonatal deaths.
  • Babies chosen for inclusion in perinatal statistics should be above a minimum birth weight (1000g at birth). If the birth weight is not available, a gestation period of at least 28 weeks should be used (as the weight at 28 weeks corresponds to 1000g). If both are not available, then crown to heel length of at least 35cm should be used.
  • Generally, the PMR = Late fetal deaths and early neonatal deaths weighing over 1000g at birth x 1000/Total births(live+dead) weighing over 1000g at birth.
  • The PMR is the yard-stick of obstetric and pediatric care before and around the time of birth.
  • The PMR of India (2016) is 24 per 1000 births.
  • The main causes of perinatal mortality are intrauterine and birth asphyxia, low birth weight, birth trauma, and intrauterine/neonatal infections.

Please note that the actual perinatal period commences from the 22nd week of life, but at that time the fetus weighs only about 500g.

Therefore, only for statistical calculations and international comparisons, to calculate the perinatal mortality rate, the period from the 28th week of life is taken, as then the baby weighs about 1000g. As mentioned, babies included in the perinatal statistics must weigh above 1000g.

questions.text: In a given population, 4050 births were recorded over a period of 1 year. Among these, 50 were stillbirths, 50 died in the 1st week of life and 150 died within 8-28 days of life. What is the neonatal mortality rate of this population?
questions.solution:
The neonatal mortality rate (NMR) of the given population is 50 per 1000 live births.

Neonatal mortality rate = No. of deaths of neonates < 28 days within a year x 1000 / Total live births in the same year

In this population, there were 4000 live births (no. of total births - no. of stillbirths).

NMR = (50+150) x 1000/4000 = 100/2 = 50

Related Pearl: Neonatal Mortality Rate

  • Neonatal deaths are those that occur during the neonatal period, commencing at birth and ending at 28 completed days after birth.
  • NMR = Number of deaths of children under 28 days of age in a year x 1000/Total live births in the same year
  • Main causes of neonatal death are prematurity (leading cause), birth asphyxia, intrapartum-related complications, sepsis, pneumonia, congenital anomalies, tetanus, diarrhea, etc.
  • India’s NMR  is 20 per 1000 live births (SRS 2020)

questions.text: Which of the following is the leading cause of neonatal mortality?
questions.solution:
Prematurity is the leading cause of neonatal mortality.

Note: According to the sample registration system (SRS 2017-19), prematurity is the leading cause of neonatal mortality. However, birth asphyxia is the most common cause of neonatal mortality in India according to medical certification of cause of death (MCCD-19). For all practical purposes, SRS data is preferred over MCCD data in case the data source is not mentioned.

Related Pearl: Neonatal Mortality Rate

  • Neonatal deaths are those that occur during the neonatal period, commencing at birth and ending at 28 completed days after birth.
  • NMR = Number of deaths of children under 28 days of age in a year x 1000/Total live births in the same year
  • Main causes of neonatal death are prematurity (leading cause), birth asphyxia, intrapartum-related complications, sepsis, pneumonia, congenital anomalies, tetanus, diarrhea, etc.
  • India’s NMR  is 20 per 1000 live births (SRS 2020)

questions.text: In children aged 1 month to 1 year, all of the following are common causes of mortality except:
questions.solution: Tetanus is not a common cause of mortality in children between the age of 1 month to 1 year (post-neonatal period). The main causes of post-neonatal deaths are diarrhea, respiratory infections, and malnutrition.

questions.text:
In a given population, there were 5100 births during the year 2020. Of these, 100 babies were stillborn. Among the living children, the following deaths were recorded. Calculate the infant mortality rate for this population.
Time of death    No. of deaths    
1st week of life 150
8-28 days of life 150
1st year of life 500
questions.solution:
The infant mortality rate (IMR) for this population is 100 / 1000 live births.

IMR = No. of deaths within 1st year of life over a period of time x 1000 / No. of live births in the same period

In this population, there were 5000 live births (5100 – 100) and 500 deaths within the 1st year of life.

Hence, IMR = 500 x 1000/5000 = 100 per 1000 live births

choices.text: It is located in the delivery room.
It is for sick babies and LBW babies < 1800 g
It is present in all community health centres
All cases except major surgeries are managed here

questions.solution:
A newborn stabilization unit is present in all community health centers (CHC).

questions.text: You are a doctor at a child health clinic. You will consider all of the following children as at-risk infants except:

choices.text: A 15-day-old baby with birth weight of 2.4 kgs
An 8-month-old baby being raised by a working mother

questions.solution:
The 2-month-old baby with 3 older siblings has a birth order of 4. Infants with birth order of 5 or more are considered at-risk infants.

The following are considered at-risk infants:

  • Birth weight < 2.5 kgs
  • Twins 
  • Birth order of 5 or more
  • Artificial feeding
  • Weight below 70% of the expected weight
  • Failure to gain weight during 3 successive months
  • Children with protein-energy malnutrition (PEM), diarrhea
  • Working mother or single parent

questions.text: A researcher is calculating the child survival indices for different populations. Which of the following should he use for calculating the same?
questions.solution: The under-5 mortality rate is used in the calculation of the child survival index. It is calculated as (1000 – Under-5 mortality rate)/10.

questions.text: Identify the false statement about the following tool:

choices.text: Malnutrition can be detected even before signs and symptoms appear
It provides an objective basis for policy making on child healthcare
It can be used to teach the importance of adequate feeding
It can be used to indicate proof of government aid

questions.solution:
The given image shows a growth chart. It is not used as proof of government aid.

The uses of growth charts are as follows:

  • Growth monitoring and diagnosis - can detect malnutrition before clinical features appear
  • Educational tool - to teach parents about the importance of adequate feeding.
  • Objective basis for planning and policy-making on child healthcares

questions.text: A juvenile delinquent was sentenced by the court to be placed in a center under the care of a doctor and psychiatrist. Which of the following fulfills this requirement?
questions.solution:
A remand home is an establishment where children are placed under the care of a doctor, psychiatrist and other trained personnel.

An orphanage or shelter home is an institution where children who have no home or parents or for some reason can’t be cared for are placed.

Foster homes are arrangements where a family or a couple takes care of a child on a temporary basis.

Borstal is a place that falls between a certified institution and a prison. It is where boys > 16 years who have misbehaved or are too difficult to handle are sent.

questions.text: The police authorities rescued a girl from being trafficked for sexual exploitation. She is identified to be a refugee. As a part of the Ujjawala scheme, which of the following benefits will she not receive?
questions.solution:
The girl will not receive remuneration (monetary compensation) under the Ujjawala scheme.

The Ujjawala scheme was launched to combat women and child trafficking in India. The components of the scheme include:

  • Prevention of trafficking by awareness, vigilance, education
  • Rescue of victims from the place of exploitation
  • Rehabilitation of victims
  • Re-integration of victims into their family and society
  • Repatriation of cross-border victims to their place of origin

Some other legislations associated with children in India are:

  • The Right of Children to Free and Compulsory Education Act, 2009
  • Juvenile Justice (Care and Protection of Children) Act, 2000
  • Child Labour (Prohibition and Regulation) Act, 1986 (amended in 2006 and 2016)
  • Protection of Children from Sexual Offences (POCSO), 2012 under the National Commission for Protection of Child Rights (NCPCR)
  • Prohibition of Child Marriage Act, 2006

questions.text: A 4-year-old girl was brought by her parents who tell you that she fell down while playing. On examination, bruises and ecchymoses of varying ages are noted all over the body. An x-ray showed a spiral fracture of the right femur. Which of the following programs can provide support services to this child and prevent further such incidents?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario points towards child abuse. The INSPIRE strategy was introduced to eliminate such violence against children and also provide support services.

It refers to a set of 7 evidence-based strategies to eliminate violence against children:

  • Banning violent punishment of children and criminalizing sexual abuse
  • Preventing alcohol misuse and limiting youth access to weapons
N Norms and values
  • Changing perceptions about harmful gender and social norms

  • Reducing the spread of violence 
P Parent and caregiver support
  • Delivered through home visits and in groups in community settings 
I Income and economic strengthening
  • Cash transfers 
  • Providing small loans 
R Response and support services
  • Counseling and therapy
  • Treatment programs for juvenile offenders 
  • Foster care interventions
E Education and life skills
  • Increasing enrolment in schools 
  • Establishing safe school environments
  • Improving sexual education for children and teaching self-defense strategies

questions.text: As a PHC medical officer,  which of the following groups would you target as a part of Kishori Shakti Yojana?
questions.solution:
The Kishori Shakti Yojana (KSY) program is aimed at adolescent girls (11-18 years). 

This program is a component of the Integrated Child Development Services (ICDS) scheme and is a redesign of the already existing Adolescent Girls (AG) scheme.

The objectives of KSY are:

  • To improve the nutrition, health, and development status 
  • To promote awareness on health, hygiene, nutrition, and family care
  • To teach life skills and encourage school attendance
  • To help understand their social environment
  • Aspects aimed at empowerment and enhanced self-perception
  • To help them take initiatives to become productive members of society

It also fosters convergence with other sectoral programs, addressing the interrelated needs of adolescent girls and women.

questions.text: The school health programs are managed by which of the following?
questions.solution:
The school health programs are managed by the primary health center (PHC).

The School Health Committee (1961) in India recommended that the school health services should be a part of the general health services administered through PHCs. Formation of school health committees at the village, block, district, state, and national levels was recommended. The National School Health Council was created as an advisory and coordinating body.

PHCs provide the following school health services:

  • Screening and general assessments for -
    • Anemia/nutritional status
    • Visual acuity and hearing problems
    • Dental check-up
    • Physical disabilities
    • Learning disorders and behavior problems
  • Basic medicines for common ailments
  • Immunization 
  • Micronutrient management (vitamin A, iron, and folic acid)
  • Deworming 
  • Mid-day meal

 

 Note: National Programme for Mid-Day Meal in Schools has recently been renamed Pradhan Mantri Poshan Shakti Nirman (PM POSHAN).  

Related Pearl: Primary Health Centres-PHC

  • HWC-PHCs: Population of 30000 in plains, 20000 in hilly/tribal areas
  • Urban HWC-PHCs: Population of 50000
  • Specialist UPHC/Polyclinic (urban): Population of 2.5- 3 lakh

PHC’s and UPHC’s can be further extended to 24X7 PHC’s/UPHC’s

Bed distribution: 

HWC-PHC HWC-UPHC 24X7 HWC-PHC/UPHC
Essential: 2 beds Essential: 2 daycare beds Essential: 6 beds
Desirable: +4 beds Desirable: +4 daycare beds Desirable: +4 beds

Note: The desirable will be over and above the essential beds.

The twelve packages envisaged under Comprehensive Primary Healthcare services (CPHC): 

  1. Care in Pregnancy and Childbirth 
  2. Neonatal and Infant Health Care Services
  3. Childhood and Adolescent Health Care Services
  4. Family Planning, Contraceptive Services, and other Reproductive Health Care Services
  5. Management of Communicable Diseases: National Health Programmes
  6. General Out-patient Care for Acute Simple Illnesses and Minor Ailments
  7. Screening, Prevention, Control and Management of Non-communicable Diseases
  8. Care for Common Ophthalmic and ENT Problems
  9. Basic Oral Health Care
  10. Elderly and Palliative Health Care Services
  11. Emergency Medical Services including Burns and Trauma
  12. Screening and Basic Management of Mental Health Ailments.

Essential manpower for:

1) PHC: 12   2) UPHC: 16   3) Polyclinic: 22   4) 24x7 PHC: 23   5) 24X7 UPHC: 27

questions.text: A 68-year-old man visits your outpatient clinic for a routine follow-up. Which of the following protocols would you use to assess his health literacy?
questions.solution:
The SPEAK protocol is used to assess health literacy in the geriatric population in a clinical setting.

Health literacy is defined as the degree to which individuals have the capacity to obtain, process, and understand basic health information needed to make appropriate health decisions. The SPEAK protocol provides a simple framework that healthcare providers can use to assess literacy. SPEAK stands for:

  • S - Speech
  • P - Perception
  • E - Education
  • A - Access
  • K - Knowledge

Option A: The GATHER approach is mainly used for counseling (usually, family planning and reproductive counseling) to help people make decisions about health. It stands for:

  • G – Greet
  • A – Ask
  • T – Tell 
  • H – Help 
  • E – Explain 
  • R – Return 

Option C: The SPIKES protocol is used to convey distressing information and break bad news in an organized manner to patients and families. It stands for:

  • S - Setting
  • P - Perception
  • I - Invitation or information
  • K - Knowledge
  • E - Empathy
  • S - Summarizing or strategizing.

Option D: The S-BAR technique is used for prompt and appropriate communication among health care workers in hospital settings. It stands for:

  • S - Situation
  • B - Background
  • A - Assessment
  • R - Recommendation

questions.text: Which of the following comes under the Rashtriya Varishth Jan Swasthya Yojana?

choices.text: Domiciliary visits to homes of elderly in the community by ANMs or male HCWs
Rehabilitation units with physiotherapy at CHCs
Super-specialty geriatric departments for training, guidelines and referral
Weekly geriatric clinics arranged at PHCs by medical officer

questions.solution:
The establishment of super-specialty geriatric departments for training, guidelines, and referral comes under the Rashtriya Varishth Jan Swasthya Yojna (RVJSY). It refers to the tertiary component of the National Programme for Healthcare of the Elderly (NPHCE).

The NPHCE was established for geriatric care and includes provisions at primary, secondary, and tertiary levels.

Centers  Services according to NPHCE
PHCs (primary)
  • Weekly geriatric clinics at PHC
  • Treatment of minor ailments
  • Referral services to higher centers
Sub-centres (primary)
  • ANMs/ male health workers make domiciliary visits to the elderly
  • Arrange supportive devices for the disabled
  • Treatment of minor ailments
CHCs (secondary)
  • Dedicated geriatric clinics twice weekly
  • Rehabilitation unit with trained physiotherapists

The tertiary component of the program has been renamed as RVJSY and has the following provisions:

  • Geriatrics departments at 20 super specialty institutions-
    • 30-bedded inpatient facility and referral treatment
    • Research and manpower development,  
    • Development of training, IEC material, and guidelines
  • Geriatric units at district hospitals (tertiary) -
    • 10 bedded geriatric ward
    • Dedicated geriatric OPD
